title: Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN) Risk Calculator
description: Identifies the likelihood of acute interstitial nephritis in at-risk patients undergoing kidney biopsy evaluation. Uses commonly available clinical and laboratory parameters to predict AIN probability.

parameters.name: local_prevalence_ain
parameters.description: Local prevalence of AIN among all kidney biopsies. Use 0.23 if unknown.

ranges.interpretation: AIN is unlikely. Consider alternative diagnoses for acute kidney injury. High negative predictive value (>90%).
Moderate probability of AIN. Consider clinical correlation and additional testing. Kidney biopsy may be warranted based on clinical judgment.
High likelihood of AIN. Strong consideration for discontinuation of potential causative medications and corticosteroid therapy. Kidney biopsy may help confirm diagnosis.

references: Moledina DG, Luciano RL, Kukova L, et al. Kidney biopsy-related complications in hospitalized patients with acute kidney disease. Clin J Am Soc Nephrol. 2018;13(11):1633-1640.
Moledina DG, Wilson FP, Kukova L, et al. Prevalence and outcomes of kidney biopsy in hospitalized patients with acute kidney injury. J Am Soc Nephrol. 2017;28(4):1342-1349.
Perazella MA, Moledina DG. Drug-induced acute interstitial nephritis. Clin J Am Soc Nephrol. 2017;12(12):2046-2049.
formula: Logistic regression model using creatinine, BUN, urine specific gravity, urine protein, and local AIN prevalence to calculate probability of acute interstitial nephritis
notes: Should only be used for patients in whom a kidney biopsy is being considered
Developed from multicenter data including Yale, Indiana University, and Johns Hopkins
Model showed AUC of 0.73-0.74 in external validation with high negative predictive value (>90%)
Helps distinguish AIN from other causes of acute kidney injury
Important for guiding decisions about medication discontinuation and corticosteroid therapy
